Actually, before even proceeding on with the test, is there a consensus about what holes in the axe Ulysses shot his arrow through? Because by looking at artistic interpretations of the scene it seems even illustrators are not of one single mind about it, either.
Was it:
1) a ring either at top of the axe's head or at the bottom of the handle, the kind of which can be used to hang a tool on a wall?
2) the hole in the axe's head where the pole goes through?
3) since the Trojan war takes place during the last stages of the Bronze Age and in turn so do the Ilyad and the Odyssey, there used to be some special kinds of cerimonial axes called "fenestrated axes" by archaelogists. These axes had one or more D-shaped holes inside the axe's blade. While I don't think memory of those axes survived later on, one can imagine they were still in use at the time the poem originated. So, in light of this, did Homer or whoever the original author was, have in mind a fenestrated axe when he described that scene?

When Homer originally wrote the myth, he really didn’t understand how a non-compound bow actually works. Any bow that would have been available to anyone at that time in human history would have shot an arrow that “waggled” for the first part of its trip toward the target. Trick shooters anticipate the motion and know exactly where the point will be. Also, the arrow will be flying in a ballistic arc because of gravity, no matter how powerful the bow is. The holes in the axe heads would have to be arranged in such an arc or be large enough to accommodate it. Only a powerful compound bow or a crossbow could accomplish such a feat because the arrow can fly straight through the center with no waggle.

It's an IMPOSSIBLE shot, and by impossible  I mean that IT CAN NOT BE DONE with the bow technology of Odysseus' day.  The central section of the bow (the riser) was off-set from the line of travel of the strings movement because of the required rigidity needed.  This (along with the archers sight picture) creates what is known as the "archers paradox"  The arrow shaft WILL be (and MUST NEEDS BE) severely bent/flexed as it is launched to get past the riser and then it will go through a cycle of harmonic flexing.  At some point this flexing will be reduced to describe a path narrow enough to pass through the axe-head eyes  BUT not until after it has slowed down enough that the fight path begins to drop at an ever increasing curve.  So the ONLY hope you have is to pre-align the openings along a known and well described trajectory.  Given modern bows and a well enclosed indoor range I could do this in ten  practice shots with eight or more cameras and a day to analyze and then  and then one actual "attempt" should do  But if I posted it on youtube you would only see the successful one shot attempt  because I'm just that much better than Odysseus and adam savage combined

Ok fact number 1. The average draw weight of a classical longbow is believed to somewhere near an astounding 175lbs. Historians as well as scientists are baffled at how they were used effectively but they were. The longbow they tried would have been no where near that strength as they were pulling it pretty easily. The compound bow they used was  probably around 100lb if not lower. So assuming that Odysseus's "bow which no man besides himself posessesd the strength to draw" is at least as strong as the average for a classical English longbow. Then the force and therefore speed of the arrow would have been almost doubled from even the compound bow. As the original fictitous bow was supposedly impossible to draw for anyone weaker than Odysseus, we can assume that it was far stronger than 175lb and would then would send the arrow far faster. According to physics the gravitational pull exerted on the arrow stays the same while the forward momentum is increased, this effectively means that the arrow has less drop over a greater distance. It flies straighter. Taking into account that it was a fictional weapon, this is still not an accurate depiction of how the arrow would have traveled in that fictional situation. For a man capable of drawing a bow with such Power this shot would have been far easier because there would have been little to know arrow drop.

So many people comment that Corridor Digital did this last year. However, there are a few things to note:
1. Corridor had larger holes which were not metal. If they were, even a slight touch of the arrow (yes, the arrow touched the sides) would've resulted in a failure.
2. Odysseus' bow was the strongest bow ever made (according to the myth) and only he could draw it. A weak bow has naturally a greater projectile drop.
3. „Shooting though axe heads“ is a vague term. Some people cut holes into the axe heads, some add rings. But it is very likely that the holes the shafts are attached to are meant here, and shooting through multiple of those is nearly impossible.

In the epic, the bow was nigh-impossible to string.  Therefore it's a very stiff bow.  Thus a very POWERFUL bow for a powerful man.  That would make the arc of the arrow launched from it flatter in that range.  Then the question on the arrows: how much can they flex before hitting the rings?

Something to keep in mind is that a "Bow-Master" would have likely had thousands of hours of practice and peer review under their belt, or to look at it in another way, today many of us drive cars, we drive them in the rain, snow, wind, we drive them in the day and at night and on roads who's condition sometimes begs the question if they deserve to be called roads and on occasions at speeds that are far far over the rated limits of the roads we drive on, and this is a skill today that we are all adept at and some we can truly say are masters of.  In say 4 thousand years when all cars have been AI driven for at least a thousand years the thought that a human of thousands of years ago could drive could very well be the topic of some distant spin-off of this show where they discuss how plausible it could be that primitive humans could do such a task while they themselves are dismissive of the tools of today that we have learned to master.
